animalOfTheDay.name: squirrel
facts: Squirrels communicate with each other using tail flicking and vocalizations.
They can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst.
Squirrels plant thousands of trees each year by forgetting where they buried their acorns.
Some species of squirrels can leap up to 20 feet between trees.

calendar.name: skunk
facts: Skunks are known for their ability to spray a foul-smelling liquid as a defense mechanism, which can reach up to 10 feet.
Before spraying, skunks usually give a warning by stomping their feet or raising their tail.
They are immune to snake venom and will sometimes eat venomous snakes.
Skunks are nocturnal and have poor eyesight but an excellent sense of smell and hearing.

calendar.name: snail
facts: Snails can sleep for up to three years if the weather isn't favorable.
The largest land snail, the African giant snail, can grow up to 15 inches long.
They have thousands of tiny teeth on their tongue-like radula, which they use to scrape food.
Snails are hermaphrodites, meaning each individual has both male and female reproductive organs.

calendar.name: snow leopard
facts: Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.
They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.

calendar.name: snowy owl
facts: Their feathers are nearly entirely white, providing perfect camouflage in snowy environments.
Unlike most owls, they are diurnal and hunt both day and night in the Arctic tundra.
Snowy owls are one of the largest owl species, with a wingspan of up to 5 feet.
Snowy owls can detect prey moving beneath the snow using their exceptional hearing.

calendar.name: spider
facts: Spiders are not insects; they are arachnids, with eight legs and two body segments.
All spiders produce silk, but not all spiders spin webs to catch prey.
Some spiders can 'balloon' by releasing silk threads to catch the wind and travel long distances.
The venom of most spiders is harmless to humans, with only a few species being dangerous.

calendar.name: squid
facts: They can change color rapidly to communicate or camouflage, using specialized cells called chromatophores.
Squid have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, and one pumps it to the rest of the body.
The giant squid is the largest invertebrate, with eyes the size of dinner plates.
Some squid species can 'fly' by propelling themselves out of the water and gliding for short distances.

calendar.name: squirrel
facts: Squirrels plant thousands of trees each year by forgetting where they buried their acorns.
Some species of squirrels can leap up to 20 feet between trees.
They can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst.
Squirrels communicate with each other using tail flicking and vocalizations.

randomAnimals.name: mongoose
facts: Mongooses are famous for their ability to fight and kill venomous snakes.
They have specialized acetylcholine receptors that make them resistant to snake venom.
Mongooses live in groups and communicate through a variety of vocalizations.
Some species, like the meerkat, are highly social and cooperative.

randomAnimals.name: goose
facts: Geese mate for life and can live over 25 years.
They fly in V-formation to conserve energy during long migrations.
Geese have excellent memories and can remember migration routes for life.
They can fly at altitudes up to 29,000 feet.

randomAnimals.name: cobra
facts: Cobras can 'stand up' by raising up to one-third of their body length.
Despite their reputation, they prefer to avoid confrontation with humans.
They spread their hood as a warning display when threatened.
King cobras are the longest venomous snakes in the world.
